Description: Fine and relatively large scarab but very flat, made of glazed steatite, part of one leg is chipped of. Beige steatite and remains of a whitish glaze. The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. Prothorax and elytra are divided with a double line, from the lower line the humeral callosities are shown with a filled triangle. The suture is shown in a double line as well. The head has an oval shape, both eyes indicated by very small circles. The clypeus is shown with a short row of four lobes, divided by three notches, and then a second row further down with again four lobes and three notches is shown. The plates are visible as well. The side shows three fully carved legs on each side, above a base plate. The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, inside a cartouche of Mn-kheper-R' with two feathers above and two uraei at each side, facing outwards. Above the head of each uraeus a small round sign that could be a stylised crown. Underneath all a nb-basket. The orientation of the seal follows the longitudinal perforation that is fully preserved. At the lower left area a patch of black accretion.
Bibliographic references: Spencer 1997 / Amara West I, The Architectural Report (p. 25)
